summary: A traditional, curriculum-forward Maths paper with a strong emphasis on clear written working: arithmetic, fractions/percentages, linear equations, geometry facts, and number properties. Questions are mostly structured short-answer with multi-part items and occasional “explain why” prompts; there is no multiple-choice in the provided paper.

topicWeighting.topic: fractions, decimals, percentages (incl. fraction of measures and % of amounts)
linear equations (one-step and two-step, including forming equations from words)
measurement (volume of cuboids, packing/counting cubes, appropriate units)
geometry properties (parallel/perpendicular, classifying quadrilaterals, marking equal sides/angles)
angle reasoning (missing angles, angle facts; diagrams not to scale)
ratio and proportion (recipe scaling, reverse scaling)
number theory (factors, sums of factors, constraints on coin combinations)

formatRules: Instructions specify: pencil and ruler needed; no calculator; answers written in spaces provided; use spare space for working; check answers at the end.
Time allowed is 45 minutes; question set is modest in count but many questions have multiple subparts, so pacing matters.
Most questions explicitly request “showing all your working” or imply it; generators should encourage working even when the final answer is short.

Questioning style is direct and procedural for core skills (money totals, long multiplication/division, % of amounts), then moves into applied reasoning (film-time allocations, coin totals, recipe scaling, factor-sum puzzle).
Algebra emphasis is strong: many one-step and two-step linear equations, plus forming an equation from a word description and solving it.

Geometry includes: marking equal sides/angles/parallel lines on given shapes; identifying named shapes from a labelled point grid (square/rectangle/isosceles triangle/parallelogram/trapezium); and stating shared properties of families of shapes.

There is at least one explicit explanation prompt (e.g., why a quadrilateral cannot have exactly three right angles); generators should include occasional short reasoning/explanation items alongside calculations.
Angle questions are diagram-based with the note “diagrams are not drawn to scale”; solutions rely on angle facts rather than measurement.
Unit sense is tested: some questions ask for the “most appropriate unit” and combine fractions/decimals with measures and mass.
Proportion is tested via recipe scaling up/down and reverse inference (given 5 eggs, infer intended servings).
Number theory appears via factors and sums-of-factors framed as an invented “King’s Digit” game; multi-part exploration includes inverse problems and multiple-solution constraints.
Coins problem uses equal counts of denominations and a total value; generators should include at least one constrained integer-solution problem of this type.

maths.difficultyNotes: Overall difficulty is moderate-to-hard for 11+ because it expects reliable core skills under time pressure plus competent algebra, geometry facts, and multi-constraint reasoning (time allocations, coin totals, factor-sum inverses). It is less “novel puzzle” heavy than some schools, but the later number-theory game and constraint problems provide stretch.

commonWrongAnswers: Arithmetic slips in money and long multiplication/division (place value errors; forgetting decimal alignment).
Percentage and fraction-of-a-quantity errors (treating 28% as 0.28 vs 28; mishandling mixed units).
Equation-solving mistakes (incorrect inverse operation order; mishandling fractions like (1/4)x = 7).
Geometry vocabulary confusion (trapezium vs parallelogram; isosceles conditions; parallel marking).
Angle-fact errors caused by assuming diagrams are to scale or forgetting supplementary/vertically-opposite angle rules.
Proportion scaling errors (scaling ingredients inconsistently; failing to use a single scale factor).
Factor-sum misconceptions (missing 1 or the number itself; mixing up factors with multiples; overlooking multiple solutions).
Constraint problems mishandled by not setting up integer conditions (coin counts equal; totals must match exactly).
markingAndFeedback.explanationTone: Clear, calm, and methodical: restate the goal, show the minimal reliable steps, and include a quick reason/check (units check, substitution back into an equation, or verifying factors) so a child can self-correct.

generatorHints: Do NOT copy any original questions.
Match the flavour, not the exact content.
Avoid references to printing or PDFs.
Keep questions suitable for an online timed exam.
Prefer a straightforward, syllabus-aligned style: lots of short-answer items with working, plus a handful of multi-part applied questions.
Include a noticeable algebra component (several one-step and two-step equations, plus at least one ‘form an equation then solve’ word problem).
Include geometry identification/marking tasks and a small set of angle-fact questions labelled ‘not to scale’.
Include at least one proportion/recipe scaling task and one number-theory ‘game’ built on factors and sums of factors.
Use clean integer-friendly numbers for most questions, but allow a few decimals and percentages to test accuracy.
